You guys know me. Always happy to correct anyone.
 
 As electrolyte pointed out, (1) the first step in the scientific method is the observation. A scientist observes something that raises a question. (2) Then comes the hypothesis, that is an attempt to explain the observation. The hypothesis can be an educated guess or even wild speculation based on previous knowledge or intuition, or it may be based in previous science and an understanding of scientific principles. (3) One then makes a prediction that is a necessary consequence of the hypothesis. That science is predictive is one of its salient characteristics. In the case of the scientific method, the prediction is said to have the power to falsify the hypothesis. In other words, if the prediction can be shown to be false, then the hypothesis must also be false. If the prediction is true, then the hypothesis is supported. So now we have the observation, the hypothesis that explains the observation, and a prediction that is a consequence of the hypothesis. The next step (4) is to design an experiment to test the prediction, and then (5) to perform the test. If the prediction fails the test, then it may be abandoned. However, as electrolyte pointed out, the process may be circular, because if the prediction is falsified, additional observation from the test may be used to adjust the hypothesis at (2), and a new prediction is made at (3), and so on.
 
 In creation science, the process stops at (2), except that the hypothesis is based on dogma and scripture, not reality.

The tautology argument is rooted in the Spencerian epithet for natural selection, "survival of the fittest." Which organisms survive? The fittest. Which are the fittest? Those who survive. But of course, "survival of the fittest" isn't a very good statement of the theory of natural selection. Darwin didn't like it and only began using it due to the encouragement of Wallace after it had become popular. It first appeared in "On The Origin Of Species" in the 4th edition, and it was never used without an explicit reference to natural selection.

 prschuster:
 The key, here, is that *ADAPTIVE* changes are passed on to future generations via differential reproduction rates. This distinguishes it from neutral selection, genetic drift and gene flow. Those other nonadaptive changes come along for the ride, but they are not essential to evolutionary adaptation (unless a neutral trait is selected for later on). If natural selection (NS) were a tautology, it would be indistinguishable from these other mechanisms. Also, without the existence of adaptive changes being passed down to future generations, there would be no way to falsify NS or to use it for predictive purposes. I think this was what Karl Popper failed to understand when he first characterized NS as a tautology. 
 
 But we can make some very basic predictions based on NS. We can predict that the artiodactyls that evolved into whales & dolphins would have progressively more aquadynamic features because they are adaptive. If we repeatedly saw maladaptive features evolving in lineages, like the reduction of limb girdles in the ichthyostegid line, then it would be a serious problem for the theory. But we almost always see changes which make the organism better adapted - not maladapted. Anyway, this is the crux of my response to the tautology argument. In short, NS does not happen as a result of differential reproductive success; NS causes that success. 
 
 One very good analogy I have seen is taken from a phrase used in sports: "May the best team win". The best team usually wins the majority of their games BECAUSE they are the best team. They have better hitters, pitchers, quarter backs, goalies etc... They aren't better because they win more games; they win more games because they are better. In other words, just because a weak team may occassionally beat a better team it doesn't follow that they suddenly become the better team. No one would make that assertion. Neither should anyone assert that NS can be defined exclusively on the basis of which traits happen to be passed onto the next generation.
